description: Borrowed from Middle French bouel, from Old French boïel, from Latin botellus, diminutive of botulus (“sausage”). Doublet of boyau.

entries.meaning: (chiefly medicine) A part or division of the intestines, usually the large intestine.
(in the plural) The entrails or intestines; the internal organs of the stomach.
(in the plural, figuratively) The (deep) interior of something.
examples: The treasures were stored in the bowels of the ship.

entries.meaning: (in the plural, archaic) The seat of pity or the gentler emotions; pity or mercy.
examples: Bloody Bonner, that corpulent tyrant, full (as one said) of guts, and empty of bowels.

verbs.description: bowel (third-person singular simple present bowels, present participle bowelling or (US) boweling, simple past and past participle bowelled or (US) boweled)

examples: Their bodies are first bowelled, then dried upon hurdles till they be very dry [...].
